questions.text:
Which of the following conditions occur due to increased blood volume to any organ?
i Hyperemia
ii Necrosis
iii Congestion
iv Odema
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hyperaemia and congestion are the two physiological or pathological processes associated with increased blood volume within a tissue.

  • Hyperaemia is an active process resulting from increased arterial inflow, leading to augmented blood volume in the capillary beds (e.g., during inflammation or skeletal muscle activity).
  • Congestion is a passive process resulting from impaired venous outflow from a tissue (e.g., in congestive heart failure), leading to blood stasis and increased intravascular volume.
  • Necrosis and oedema may occur as complications of severe congestion, but are not primary features of increased blood volume.

Related Important Points:

Key Takeaway:
 Only hyperaemia and congestion represent conditions of increased blood volume in tissues, though by different mechanisms.

choices.text: Both statements are true and are causally related
Both statements are true but not causally related.
The first statement is true and the second is false.

questions.text: Assertion: Hyperaemia is an active process resulting from arteriolar dilation and increased blood inflow. Reason: Erythema occurs in affected tissue because of increased delivery of oxygenated blood.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hyperaemia is defined as an active increase in blood volume within tissues due to arteriolar dilation, commonly seen in inflammation or increased metabolic activity.
This results in an increased flow of oxygenated blood, which manifests as erythema (redness) in the affected area.

  • In contrast, congestion is a passive process due to impaired venous outflow, often resulting in cyanosis.
  • Therefore, the assertion is true and the reason is also true, and both are causally related; arteriolar dilation increases oxygenated blood delivery, causing visible redness.

Key Takeaway:
 Hyperaemia leads to erythema due to increased arteriolar blood flow and oxygenation of the tissue.

questions.text: All the following are microscopic features of acute pulmonary congestion EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Acute pulmonary congestion is characterised by vascular and parenchymal changes due to sudden backup of blood in the pulmonary circulation.

  • Engorgement of alveolar capillaries is a hallmark of congestion.(Option A)
  • Alveolar septal oedema results from increased hydrostatic pressure.(Option B)
  • Intra-alveolar haemorrhage may be seen in severe cases due to capillary rupture .(Option C)
  • Fibrosis of alveolar septa, however, is not a feature of acute congestion-it is seen in chronic pulmonary congestion due to prolonged hypoxia and inflammation.

Related Important Points:

Key Takeaway:
Alveolar septal fibrosis is a feature of chronic, not acute, pulmonary congestion.

questions.text: A patient presented in an emergency department with a complaint of severe pain in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. The doctor finds massive hepatomegaly on clinical examination. The image below shows the cut section of the liver. What are the suggestive changes seen in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of a mottled appearance with centrilobular congestion and necrosis, surrounded by relatively normal periportal tissue, creates the “nutmeg liver” seen in chronic passive congestion, most commonly due to right-sided heart failure.

  • Central zones (zone 3) undergo congestion and necrosis.
  • Peripheral (periportal) hepatocytes may appear viable or fatty.
  • Repeated hypoxia leads to fibrosis and hemorrhagic necrosis in the long term.

Related Important Points:

Explanation of other options:

Acute passive congestion (Option A): Characterised by dilated central veins and congestion but lacks the chronic changes like fibrosis and nutmeg appearance.

Acute active congestion (Option C): Not a recognised histopathological term in this context.

Chronic active congestion (Option D): Misnomer; the correct terminology is chronic passive congestion.

Key Takeaway:
 "Nutmeg liver" is a hallmark of chronic passive congestion caused by right heart failure.

questions.text: Heart failure cells are seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hemosiderin-laden macrophages, known as heart failure cells, are characteristic of long-standing pulmonary venous congestion.

  • In chronic pulmonary congestion, persistent high pressure in the pulmonary veins causes red cell extravasation into the alveoli.
  • Alveolar macrophages phagocytose RBCs, break down haemoglobin, and store iron as hemosiderin, leading to the formation of heart failure cells.
  • These cells are typically found in lung biopsy specimens from patients with left-sided heart failure.
  • The interalveolar septa also become thickened and fibrotic over time.

Explanation of other options:

Acute pulmonary congestion (Option A): Shows alveolar capillary engorgement and oedema but not hemosiderin-laden macrophages.

Congestive cardiac arrest (Option C): Not a pathological term-refers to the sudden cessation of heart function, not chronic congestion.

Chronic hepatitis (Option D): Involves liver inflammation; unrelated to pulmonary hemosiderin-laden macrophages.

Key Takeaway:
 Heart failure cells are hemosiderin-laden macrophages found in the lungs during chronic pulmonary congestion, a hallmark of left-sided heart failure.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of deep vein thrombosis presents with a sudden onset of dyspnea and pleuritic chest pain. A CT pulmonary angiogram reveals an embolus in a segmental pulmonary artery. Which of the following best explains the red appearance of the resulting pulmonary infarct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The red appearance of pulmonary infarcts is due to the dual circulation from both the pulmonary and bronchial arteries.

  • Pulmonary infarcts occur due to embolic occlusion of pulmonary arteries.
  • Lungs have a dual blood supply: the pulmonary arteries and bronchial arteries.
  • Although the pulmonary artery is occluded, the bronchial arteries continue to supply some blood to the infarcted area, which leaks into necrotic tissue → hemorrhagic (red) infarct.
  • The loose alveolar structure further facilitates the accumulation of extravasated blood.

RED INFARCTS IN LUNGS

Related Important Points:

  • Red infarcts are seen in: lungs, small intestine, testes (torsion), and brain (sometimes reperfused infarcts).
  • White infarcts are typical of solid, end-arterial organs: the kidney, spleen, and heart.
  • Venous infarction can also lead to hemorrhagic infarction due to back-pressure.

Explanation of other options:

End-arterial blood supply (Option A): This leads to white infarcts, not red.

High alveolar oxygen tension (Option B): Not related to infarct colour; impacts oxygenation, not haemorrhage.

Lack of collateral circulation (Option D): This causes white infarcts, not red.

Key Takeaway:
 Dual circulation (pulmonary + bronchial arteries) makes the lungs prone to red infarcts when pulmonary vessels are occluded.

questions.text: Which of the following changes are seen in infarction microscopically?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Infarcts in most solid organs show ischemic coagulative necrosis on microscopy.

  • Coagulative necrosis results from ischemic injury due to arterial obstruction.
  • It preserves basic tissue architecture initially, though cellular detail is lost.
  • Most commonly seen in solid organs: heart, kidney, spleen, etc.
  • Exception: Brain infarcts show liquefactive necrosis due to high lipid and enzyme content.

Related Important Points:

  • Infarction = localised area of ischemic necrosis caused by vascular occlusion.
  • The type of necrosis depends on tissue type and duration of ischemia.
  • Inflammatory response follows necrosis, later replaced by fibrosis/scarring.

Explanation of other options:

Caseous necrosis (Option A): Seen in granulomatous diseases like tuberculosis, not infarction.

Fat necrosis (Option B): Occurs in acute pancreatitis or trauma to adipose-rich areas.

Fibrinoid necrosis (Option D): Seen in immune-mediated vascular damage, not infarcts.

Key Takeaway:
 Microscopically, infarcts in most tissues show coagulative necrosis except in the brain, which shows liquefactive necrosis.

questions.text: Which of the following organs does NOT show Pale infarcts?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

White (pale) infarcts occur in solid organs with end-arterial circulation, where limited collateral blood flow leads to anaemic necrosis.

  • Organs likethe heart, spleen, and kidney have compact tissue and end-arterial blood supply → favour pale infarcts.
  • The lungs, however, havea dual blood supply (pulmonary + bronchial arteries) and loose spongy architecture, which allows blood to seep into the necrotic area, causing red (hemorrhagic) infarcts.

Related Important Points:

  • White infarcts: Heart, kidney, spleen (dense tissues, end-arterial supply).
  • Red infarcts: Lung, small intestine, testis (loose tissue or dual supply).
  • The type of infarct also depends on whether the occlusion is arterial or venous, and whether reperfusion occurs.

Explanation of other options:

Spleen (Option B): End-arterial organ → classically shows pale infarct.

Kidney (Option C): Compact, solid organ with end-arterial branches → pale infarct.

Heart (Option D): Also has limited collateral circulation → results in pale infarcts.

Key Takeaway:
 Lungs do not show pale infarcts due to dual circulation and loose tissue; instead, they develop red (hemorrhagic) infarcts.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a three-month history of ankle swelling was admitted to the hospital. He had severe congestive cardiac failure with massive oedema and ascites. A fairly diuretic followed treatment, but the ankle swelling persisted. Fourteen days after admission, he suddenly collapsed and died. On autopsy, the left coronary artery was partly occluded by an atheroma, with infarction of the wall of the left ventricle. Identify the lesion in the image.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows a classic white (anaemic) infarct in the spleen.

  • White infarcts occur in solid organs with end-arterial circulation, likethe spleen, kidney, and heart.
  • The lesion is pale, wedge-shaped, with the apex pointing to the hilum and the base toward the capsule.
  • The infarct appears sharply demarcated due to a lack of collateral flow and dense parenchyma.
  • In splenic infarcts, occlusion is usually arterial and commonly due to thromboembolism or atherosclerosis.

Related Important Points:

  • White infarcts: Seen in spleen, heart, kidney- organs with end-arterial blood supply.
  • Red infarcts: Seen in the lung, intestine - organs with dual circulation or loose tissue.
  • Splenic infarcts may be asymptomatic or cause left upper quadrant pain.

Explanation of other options:

Red infarct of lung (Option B): Appears hemorrhagic, not pale; occurs in dual blood supply organs like lungs.

Caseous necrotic lesion (Option C): Seen in granulomatous conditions like TB, not infarcts.

Metastatic nodule of liver (Option D): Typically multiple, rounded masses, not wedge-shaped infarcts.

Key Takeaway:
 White infarcts are wedge-shaped, pale, and seen in solid organs like the spleen with end-arterial supply.

questions.text:
Assertion: Septic infarctions occur when infected cardiac valve vegetations embolize
Reason: Septic infarct gets converted into a granuloma.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Septic infarcts occur due to infected emboli (e.g., from cardiac vegetations), but they form abscesses, not granulomas.

  • Septic infarcts occur when emboli from infected cardiac valves (e.g., in infective endocarditis) occlude blood vessels, introducing microbes into ischemic tissue.
  • These infarcts are converted into abscesses, which elicit intense neutrophilic inflammation and lead to healing by organisation and fibrosis.
  • Granulomas, on the other hand, are associated with chronic infections like tuberculosis and involve a different immunological response (macrophages, lymphocytes, giant cells); not typical of septic infarcts.

Key Takeaway:
 Septic infarcts result in abscess formation, not granulomas, due to microbial infection of infarcted tissue.

questions.text:
Assertion: Increased hydrostatic pressures lead to oedema
Reason: Increased hydrostatic pressures cause increased movement of water into the interstitium
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Oedema results directly from increased hydrostatic pressure that forces fluid out of the vasculature into the interstitial space.

  • Oedema is defined as the abnormal accumulation of fluid in interstitial tissue spaces.
  • One of the most common causes is increased hydrostatic pressure, especially in conditions such as venous obstruction or congestive heart failure.
  • This pressure increases the filtration of fluid through the capillary wall into the interstitium, leading to transudative oedema.
  • The relationship is causal, as the increased pressure directly increases transcapillary fluid movement.

Key Takeaway:

Increased hydrostatic pressure is a direct and common cause of oedema due to enhanced fluid movement into the interstitial space.

questions.text:
Which of the following mechanisms contributes to the development of thrombosis?
i. Endothelial Injury
ii. Abnormal Blood Flow
iii. Hypercoagulability
iv. Inflammation
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Thrombosis is classically driven by Virchow's triad: endothelial injury, abnormal blood flow, and hypercoagulability.

Virchow's triad of thrombosis:

  • Endothelial Injury (i): Disruption of the endothelium exposes subendothelial collagen and tissue factor, triggering platelet adhesion and coagulation.
  • Abnormal Blood Flow (ii): Turbulence and stasis promote thrombosis by disrupting laminar flow and bringing platelets into contact with the endothelium.
  • Hypercoagulability (iii): An increased tendency to thrombosis due to genetic or acquired clotting disorders.
  • Inflammation (iv): While it may promote a procoagulant state indirectly, it is not a standalone component of Virchow's triad.

Key Takeaway:

Virchow's triad-endothelial injury, abnormal blood flow, and hypercoagulability-is the primary mechanisms that lead to thrombosis.

questions.text:
Which of the following types of shock occurs due to a decrease in peripheral vascular resistance?
i. Hypovolemic shock
ii. Neurogenic shock
iii. Cardiogenic shock
iv. Septic shock
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Neurogenic and septic shock are caused by profound vasodilation and decreased systemic vascular resistance.

  • Neurogenic shock (ii): Occurs due to sudden loss of sympathetic tone following spinal cord injury or anaesthesia, leading to vasodilation and pooling of blood in the periphery.
  • Septic shock (iv): Triggered by systemic infection (often gram-negative bacteria), releasing inflammatory mediators like TNF-α and IL-1, causing widespread vasodilation and hypotension.
  • Hypovolemic shock (i): Results from fluid or blood loss with preserved or increased peripheral resistance (to maintain perfusion).
  • Cardiogenic shock (iii): Caused by pump failure with increased peripheral resistance due to compensatory vasoconstriction.

Key Takeaway:

Neurogenic and septic shock are the only major shock types characterised by reduced peripheral vascular resistance.

questions.text: Procalcitonin is used as a marker for:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Procalcitonin is an acute-phase reactant that correlates with the severity of bacterial sepsis.

  • Procalcitonin is a precursor of calcitonin, but in systemic infections (especially bacterial), it is released in large amounts from extra-thyroidal tissues.
  • It serves as a biomarker for bacterial sepsis, and its levels correlate with severity.
  • Levels are typically low in viral infections and non-infectious inflammation, making it useful in differentiating bacterial causes.
  • It is often used clinically to monitor response to antibiotics or to guide antibiotic therapy duration in sepsis.

Explanation of other options:

Medullary carcinoma of thyroid (Option B): Associated with increased calcitonin, not procalcitonin.

Vitamin D-resistant rickets (Option C): Involves phosphate metabolism abnormalities, not related to procalcitonin.

Parathyroid adenoma (Option D): Causes elevated PTH, not procalcitonin.

Key Takeaway:

Procalcitonin is a sensitive and specific biomarker for diagnosing and monitoring bacterial sepsis.

questions.text: All the following are sequential events in the process of hemostasis at the site of vascular injury EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hemostasis begins with arteriolar vasoconstriction, which transiently reduces blood loss after vascular injury.

  • Hemostasis is the physiological process that halts bleeding following vascular damage and comprises four sequential steps:
    • Vasoconstriction: Immediate reflex response mediated by endothelin and neurogenic mechanisms.
    • Platelet plug formation: Platelets adhere to exposed subendothelium and aggregate to form a temporary plug. (Option B)
    • Fibrin deposition: Activation of the coagulation cascade stabilises the plug with cross-linked fibrin. (Option C)
    • Clot stabilisation and resorption: Fibrinolysis and tissue repair mechanisms remodel and remove the clot. (Option D)
  • Arteriolar vasodilation would increase blood flow, contradicting the primary goal of minimising haemorrhage.

Key Takeaway:

The first step of hemostasis is vasoconstriction; vasodilation is not part of the normal sequence.

questions.text: Which is the most common mechanism that leads to oedema in nephrotic syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Nephrotic syndrome causes loss of albumin in urine, leading to decreased plasma oncotic pressure and generalised oedema.

  • Nephrotic syndrome is characterised by heavy proteinuria (>3.5 g/day), hypoalbuminemia, generalised oedema, hyperlipidemia, and lipiduria.
  • Loss of albumin via damaged glomerular capillaries reduces plasma oncotic pressure, resulting in fluid shifting from intravascular to interstitial compartments.
  • This fluid accumulation causes generalised pitting oedema, especially in dependent areas.
  • Hypoalbuminemia also triggers secondary hyperaldosteronism and sodium/water retention, aggravating the oedema.

Explanation of other options:

Na+ and water restriction (Option A): This is a treatment modality, not a mechanism for oedema development.

Increased venous pressure (Option B): Seen in conditions like CHF or DVT; not the mechanism in nephrotic syndrome.

Decreased fibrinogen (Option D): Plays no role in oncotic pressure or oedema formation in nephrotic syndrome.

Key Takeaway:

Hypoalbuminemia due to proteinuria is the primary driver of oedema in nephrotic syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is a procoagulant protein?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Thrombin is a central procoagulant enzyme that converts fibrinogen to fibrin and activates platelets.

  • Thrombin plays a key procoagulant role in secondary hemostasis.
  • It is generated in the coagulation cascade following activation of Factor VII by tissue factor.
  • The functions of thrombin include:
    • Conversion of soluble fibrinogen to insoluble fibrin, forming a stable clot
    • Activation of platelets, amplifying clot formation
    • Activation of cofactors such as Factor V, VIII, and XI, reinforcing the coagulation cascade
  • This cascade is essential to consolidate the initial platelet plug into a definitive thrombus.

Key Takeaway:

Thrombin is a potent procoagulant that catalyses the formation of fibrin and activates platelets.

questions.text: Which is the commonest site of thrombosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Venous thrombosis is the most common type of thrombosis, especially in the lower extremities.

  • Venous thrombi (phlebothrombosis) are almost always occlusive and often extend toward the heart.
  • These thrombi develop in areas of slow blood flow or stasis, which is typical of the venous system.
  • Lower limb deep veins (e.g., femoral, popliteal) are the most commonly affected sites, accounting for nearly 90% of venous thromboses.
  • Venous thrombi are rich in red blood cells and fibrin, giving them a red appearance.
  • Risk factors include immobility, post-surgical states, and hypercoagulable conditions.

Explanation of other options:

Artery (Option B): Arterial thrombi are less common and usually form over atherosclerotic plaques or sites of endothelial injury.

Heart (Option C): Intracardiac thrombi may occur in conditions like atrial fibrillation or after myocardial infarction, but are not the most common overall.

Capillary (Option D): Capillaries are too small and have high perfusion pressure, making thrombosis extremely rare.

Key Takeaway:

Veins, especially of the lower limbs, are the most frequent site of thrombus formation due to stasis and low-flow conditions.

questions.text: What is the most common source of embolism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The majority of emboli originate from thrombi, with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) being the most common source.

  • An embolus is a detached intravascular solid, liquid, or gaseous mass transported by blood to a distant site.
  • Pulmonary embolism is the most frequent form of thromboembolic disease and typically arises from DVT of the lower limbs.
  • Risk factors for DVT include prolonged immobility, hypercoagulable states, surgery, and malignancy.
  • The embolus may lodge in the pulmonary arteries, causing impaired gas exchange, infarction, or sudden death.

Explanation of other options:

Trauma (Option B): May cause fat embolism, but is far less common than DVT-related emboli.

Infection (Option C): Septic emboli occur in endocarditis but are not the most common overall.

Surgery (Option D): Can lead to embolism (e.g., air or thrombotic), but DVT is a more frequent and major source.

Key Takeaway:

Deep vein thrombosis is the most common source of emboli, particularly pulmonary embolism.

questions.text: Which of the following pathophysiological mechanisms is responsible for initiating endotoxin shock?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cytokine release is the central initiating mechanism of endotoxin (septic) shock following exposure to microbial products such as LPS.

  • Microbial products (PAMPs like LPS) stimulate monocytes and macrophages to release cytokines such as TNF, IL-1, and HMGB1.
  • These cytokines activate endothelial cells, initiate coagulation, and recruit leukocytes, setting off a cascade of downstream effects.
  • The cytokine storm causes:
    • Widespread vasodilation
    • Increased vascular permeability
    • DIC and microvascular thrombosis
    • Tissue ischemia
    • Multiorgan failure


Explanation of other options:

Endothelial injury (Option A): Occurs secondary to cytokine-mediated inflammation, not the primary trigger.

Peripheral vasodilation (Option B): A consequence of cytokine effects (e.g., via NO, PAF), not the initial event.

Increased vascular permeability (Option C): Caused by cytokines and inflammatory mediators, not the initiating step.

Key Takeaway:

Cytokine release is the initiating event in endotoxin shock, triggering vasodilation, coagulation, and inflammation.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman is hospitalised after falling and fracturing her left femoral trochanter. Two weeks later, the left leg is swollen, particularly below the knee. She experiences pain on movement of the leg; on palpation, there is tenderness. Which of the following complications is most likely to occur after these events?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Immobilisation following long bone fractures increases the risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which can lead to pulmonary thromboembolism.

  • Elderly patients with hip or femoral fractures are at high risk for DVT due to venous stasis and prolonged immobilisation.
  • Classic features of DVT include calf tenderness, swelling, and pain on dorsiflexion (Homan's sign).
  • Pulmonary thromboembolism (PTE) is the most dangerous and common complication of DVT, especially if not treated early.

Explanation of other options:

Gangrenous necrosis of foot (Option A): Results from arterial insufficiency or peripheral arterial occlusion, not a sequela of DVT.

Disseminated intravascular coagulation (Option B): Typically occurs in sepsis, malignancy, trauma, or obstetric emergencies, not in isolated DVT.

Fat embolism (Option D): Seen within 24-72 hours post long bone fracture, delayed presentation at 2 weeks with unilateral leg swelling fits DVT with risk of PTE, not fat embolism.

Key Takeaway:

Pulmonary thromboembolism is the most serious and common complication of DVT following long bone fracture and immobilisation.

questions.text: Which of the following is also known as chicken fat clot?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A postmortem clot is known as a chicken fat clot due to its gelatinous consistency and yellow upper portion.

  • Postmortem clots are non-adherent, gelatinous, and show gravitational settling of red cells.
  • This gives rise to two layers:
    • Dark red dependent portion (RBC-rich)
    • Yellow supernatant ("chicken fat") layer (plasma-rich)
  • They are not attached to the vessel wall, helping distinguish them from thrombi.

Explanation of other options:

Thrombus (Option B): Firm, adherent to vessel wall, with grey fibrin strands, not a chicken fat appearance.

Infarct (Option C): Area of tissue necrosis due to ischemia not a clot, and unrelated to chicken fat morphology.

Key Takeaway:

Chicken fat clots refer to non-adherent postmortem clots showing RBC and plasma separation.

questions.text: A 66-year-old woman with congestive heart failure and progressive breathing problems died of respiratory distress. Histologic sections from lung tissue reveal numerous pigmented cells in alveoli. Which of the following is the origin of these 'Heart failure cells'?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Heart failure cells are alveolar macrophages laden with hemosiderin, formed due to chronic pulmonary congestion.

  • In left-sided heart failure, elevated pulmonary venous pressure leads to capillary leakage of RBCs into alveoli.
  • Alveolar macrophages ingest these RBCs, degrading haemoglobin into hemosiderin.
  • These iron-laden macrophages are termed "siderophages" or "heart failure cells".
  • They are hallmark features of chronic passive pulmonary congestion.

Explanation of other options:

Endothelial cells (Option A): Line blood vessels; they may leak RBCs but do not phagocytose them.

Pneumocytes (Option B): Alveolar lining cells, type I and II pneumocytes not phagocytic in function.

Lymphocytes (Option C): Involved in immune response; do not process hemosiderin or appear as heart failure cells.

Key Takeaway:

Heart failure cells are hemosiderin-laden macrophages seen in alveoli due to red cell extravasation in chronic pulmonary congestion.

questions.text:
Infarcts due to venous thrombosis are typically seen in which of the following organs?
Options:
i. Testis
ii. Brain
iii. Ovary
iv. Kidney
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Infarction due to venous thrombosis occurs primarily in organs with a single venous outflow, like the testis and ovary, because of the absence of effective collateral drainage.

  • In most organs, venous thrombosis results in congestion, but not infarction, due tothe opening of collateral venous channels.
  • However, in organs like the testis and ovary, which have single efferent veins, thrombosis leads to infarction.
  • Brain and kidney infarcts are typically arterial in origin, not due to venous thrombosis.

Key Takeaway:

Venous infarction is classically seen in organs with single venous outflow, like the testis and ovary while others develop only congestion.

questions.text: The Patient, after trauma has respiratory discomfort. Ventilation was tried but was not helpful, the histopath of the lung is given. What is the appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Fat embolism syndrome (FES) occurs when fat globules enter the bloodstream after long bone trauma, causing pulmonary microvascular obstruction and inflammation.

  • It usually presents 24-72 hours post-injury with respiratory failure, neurological symptoms, and petechial rash.
  • Histopathology reveals fat globules occluding capillaries, especially in the lungs.
  • FES is more common after fractures of the femur, pelvis, or multiple long bones.
  • Ventilation alone is insufficient due to mechanical blockage and chemical injury from circulating fat.
  • Diffuse alveolar haemorrhage with pulmonary oedema: Seen in vasculitis or left heart failure, not classic post-trauma. (Option A ruled out)
  • Diffuse damage due to ventilation pressure: May cause barotrauma, but will not produce fat globules in vessels. (Option B ruled out)

Key Takeaway:

Fat embolism is a critical complication of long bone trauma and should be suspected in respiratory distress with fat vacuoles seen in lung vessels.

questions.text:
Red infarcts are due to parallel unobstructed blood flow / dual blood supply in an infarcted area. Which organ/s have such infarcts?
i. Lung
ii. Intestine
iii. Ovary
iv. Liver
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Red infarcts occur in tissues where blood can re-enter the infarcted zone, either due to dual blood supply or venous congestion.

  • Lung (i): Has dual circulation from pulmonary and bronchial arteries; infarcts are typically hemorrhagic.
  • Intestine (ii): Supplied by extensive arterial arcades; partial perfusion from collateral vessels causes red infarction.
  • Ovary (iii): Torsion leads to venous outflow obstruction while arterial supply continues → hemorrhagic infarction.
  • Liver (iv): Although it has dual blood supply (hepatic artery and portal vein), infarcts are rare due to high regenerative capacity and efficient collateralization.

The figure shows a Hemorrhagic, roughly wedge-shaped pulmonary infarct (red infarct).

Key Takeaway:

Red infarcts occur in organs with dual blood supply or venous congestion-lungs, intestines, and ovaries are classic examples.

questions.text:
Assertion: The Lung and small intestine show red infarcts
Reason: The Lung and small intestine have dual circulation, which allows blood to flow from an unobstructed parallel supply into the necrotic zone.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Red infarcts are most commonly seen in:

  • Tissues with dual blood supply, such as lungs (pulmonary and bronchial circulation) and small intestine (via arterial arcades).
  • In such tissues, occlusion of one supply allows continued perfusion from the other, leading to blood leakage into infarcted areas, producing hemorrhagic (red) infarcts.
  • This explains both the assertion and the reason being true and causally linked.

Key Takeaway:

Red infarcts occur in organs like the lungs and intestines due to dual circulation, allowing haemorrhage into necrotic areas.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man was hospitalised 3 weeks ago for a cerebral infarction. He is now ambulating for the first time. Within minutes of returning to his hospital room, he had a sudden onset of dyspnea with diaphoresis. He cannot be resuscitated. The gross appearance of the hilum of the left lung at autopsy is shown in the figure. Which of the following risk factors most likely contributed to this finding?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) of the lower limbs is the most common source of pulmonary emboli.

  • Prolonged immobilisation post-stroke leads to venous stasis, facilitating clot formation in the deep veins of the legs or pelvis.
  • Once mobilised, a fragment of thrombus can embolize to the lungs, causing sudden fatal pulmonary thromboembolism, as seen here.
  • Elderly, bedridden patients, especially post-stroke, are at high risk.

Explanation of other options:

Antiphospholipid antibody (Option A): Can cause thrombosis but usually affects younger individuals and is less common than DVT in the elderly.

Bronchopneumonia (Option B): Can cause small vessel thrombosis, but does not cause large emboli as shown.

Factor V mutation (Option C): An inherited hypercoagulable state less common in the elderly and not typically the main trigger in immobilised patients.

Key Takeaway:

Pulmonary thromboembolism in the elderly is most commonly due to DVT from prolonged immobilisation following events like stroke

questions.text: When the baroreceptors respond to the decreased cardiac output by stimulating the sympathetic nervous system, it improves myocardial contractility and vasoconstriction, leading to increased venous return and arterial blood pressure. Which stage of shock is suspected in this mechanism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The compensatory stage of shock (also known as the early or nonprogressive stage) is characterised by activation of reflex mechanisms that attempt to maintain perfusion of vital organs.

  • Baroreceptor reflexes, sympathetic discharge, catecholamine release, and activation of the renin-angiotensin system collectively raise systemic vascular resistance, heart rate, and venous return.
  • The skin may appear pale and cool due to cutaneous vasoconstriction (except in early septic shock, which may show flushed skin due to vasodilation).
  • Perfusion to the heart and brain is preserved, while peripheral tissues begin to show signs of hypoperfusion.

Explanation of other options:

Initial stage (Option B): Refers to the very early phase where tissue hypoxia begins, but clinical signs are minima, l not yet compensatory.

Decompensated stage (Option C): Compensatory mechanisms fail; features include hypotension, metabolic acidosis, and worsening perfusion.

Refractory stage (Option D): Irreversible cell and tissue damage has occurred; recovery is no longer possible even with resuscitation.

Key Takeaway:

The compensatory (nonprogressive) stage of shock involves reflex mechanisms like sympathetic activation and baroreceptor response to maintain vital organ perfusion.

questions.text:
Assertion: Septic shock is a serious medical condition.
Reason: Septic shock causes multiple organ injury, leading to low blood pressure and abnormalities in cellular metabolism.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Septic shock is a serious life-threatening condition caused by severe infection, most often due to bacteria or fungi, resulting in a dysregulated host immune response.

  • It involves systemic vasodilation, increased vascular permeability, and widespread endothelial activation.
  • These changes result in hypotension, tissue hypoperfusion, and multi-organ dysfunction, including renal, cardiac, pulmonary, and cerebral injury.
  • Metabolic abnormalities, such as hyperglycemia and lactic acidosis, further worsen the clinical picture.
  • Hence, both the assertion and the reason are true and directly related.

Key Takeaway:

Septic shock causes widespread inflammation and metabolic dysfunction, resulting in hypotension and multiorgan failure.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male was found dead in his home. The family claimed it was dead due to a sudden MI. What is the best test to distinguish antemortem from post-mortem clot?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lines of Zahn are alternating light and dark layers formed by platelets, fibrin, and trapped red cells - seen only in antemortem thrombi.

  • These lines reflect active blood flow and formation of thrombus in the circulating system.
  • Most commonly seen in thrombi of the heart or aorta.
  • Postmortem clots lack this lamination and have a gelatinous appearance with a yellow "chicken fat" top and red "currant jelly" bottom due to gravity.

Explanation of other options:

Chicken fat (Option B): Refers to postmortem clots, not thrombi.

Red cells (Option C): Present in both thrombi and postmortem clots - not distinguishing.

White cells (Option D): Also nonspecific and do not help differentiate thrombus from clot.

Key Takeaway:

Lines of Zahn are diagnostic of antemortem thrombi and are not seen in postmortem clots.
